unnormalised: Hey folks, getting into real estate and scratching your head about "rental yields"? Don't worry, it's not rocket science!
normalised: Hey folks, getting into real estate and scratching your head about "rental yields"? Don't worry, it's not rocket science!

unnormalised: Simply put, rental yield is the return on your property investment from rental income. It's calculated as (Annual Rental Income / Property Value) x 100.
normalised: Simply put, rental yield is the return on your property investment from rental income. It's calculated as open parenthesis Annual Rental Income divided by Property Value close parenthesis multiplied by one hundred.

unnormalised: So, if you bought a flat in Bangalore for Rs. 50 lakhs, and you rent it out for Rs. 15,000 per month, your annual rental income is Rs. 1,80,000. The rental yield is then (1,80,000 / 50,00,000) x 100 = 3.6%.
normalised: So, if you bought a flat in Bangalore for rupee fifty lakhs, and you rent it out for rupee fifteen thousand per month, your annual rental income is rupee one lakh eighty thousand. The rental yield is then open parenthesis one lakh eighty thousand divided by fifty lakhs close parenthesis multiplied by one hundred equals three point six percent.

unnormalised: Now, is 3.6% good? Well, it depends! It varies based on location. A property in a prime Mumbai location might have a lower yield than a similar property in, say, Coimbatore, because of higher property prices.
normalised: Now, is three point six percent good? Well, it depends! It varies based on location. A property in a prime Mumbai location might have a lower yield than a similar property in, say, Coimbatore, because of higher property prices.

unnormalised: Also, remember to factor in expenses like property taxes (BBMP tax!), maintenance, and even the occasional *puja* you might perform during Diwali. These impact your net rental yield.
normalised: Also, remember to factor in expenses like property taxes (B B M P tax!), maintenance, and even the occasional *puja* you might perform during Diwali. These impact your net rental yield.

unnormalised: Higher yields generally mean higher risk – perhaps the property is in a less desirable area or requires significant renovation. Don't chase just high numbers, do your due diligence!
normalised: Higher yields generally mean higher risk – perhaps the property is in a less desirable area or requires significant renovation. Don't chase just high numbers, do your due diligence!

normalised: Consider this: my cousin, Priya, invested in a student-friendly one B H K near Manipal University, getting a decent yield. Location, location, location!

unnormalised: Think of rental yield as the *biryani* of real estate investing – lots of ingredients need to be just right to get the perfect taste (or return, in this case!). And it's a long-term game, folks! Good luck!
